name: Birbal Sahni
summary: Birbal Sahni was an Indian paleobotanist who founded the Birbal Sahni Institute of Palaeosciences in Lucknow. He discovered fossilized plants from the Mesozoic and Paleozoic eras in India, establishing India's geological and botanical prehistory. His work on plant evolution and continental drift was internationally recognized.
timeline: Earned DSc from University of London
Founded Birbal Sahni Institute of Palaeosciences

name: Yellapragada Subbarow
summary: Yellapragada Subbarow was an Indian-American biochemist who discovered the role of ATP in cellular energy transfer, synthesized folic acid, and developed methotrexate (one of the first anti-cancer drugs) and diethylcarbamazine (anti-parasitic). Despite these groundbreaking discoveries, he remains relatively unknown compared to peers.
timeline: Discovered role of phosphocreatine and ATP
Died in Pearl River, New York

name: Asima Chatterjee
summary: Asima Chatterjee was an Indian organic chemist who was the first woman to earn a Doctor of Science (DSc) from an Indian university. She researched the chemistry of plant alkaloids and developed anti-epileptic and anti-malarial drugs from Indian medicinal plants. She received the Padma Bhushan for her contributions to chemistry.
timeline: Earned BSc from University of Calcutta
First Indian woman to earn DSc degree

name: Janaki Ammal
summary: Janaki Ammal was an Indian botanist and cytogeneticist who pioneered research on sugarcane and eggplant hybridization. She was one of the first Indian women to earn a PhD in botany (from the University of Michigan). Her chromosome studies of plants contributed to crop improvement in India and internationally.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Michigan
Returned to India, reorganized Botanical Survey

name: Darshan Ranganathan
summary: Darshan Ranganathan was an Indian organic chemist known for her work on supramolecular chemistry and the chemical simulation of key biological processes. She developed novel methods for cyclophane and functionalized amino acid synthesis. She received the Shanti Swarup Bhatnagar Prize, India's highest science award.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Delhi

name: Anna Mani
summary: Anna Mani was an Indian physicist and meteorologist who made significant contributions to meteorological instrumentation. She standardized over 100 weather instruments at the India Meteorological Department and pioneered solar radiation and wind energy measurements in India. She published important research on atmospheric ozone measurement.
timeline: Worked with C.V. Raman on diamond spectroscopy

name: Rajeswari Chatterjee
summary: Rajeswari Chatterjee was an Indian electrical engineer who was one of the first women to earn a PhD in electrical engineering from the University of Michigan. She pioneered microwave engineering research at the Indian Institute of Science and developed antennas and microwave components used in Indian telecommunications.
timeline: Earned masters from University of Michigan
Earned PhD from University of Michigan
Joined Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore
Pioneered microwave engineering research in India

name: Tessy Thomas
summary: Tessy Thomas is an Indian aerospace engineer known as the 'Missile Woman of India.' She served as Project Director for the Agni-IV and Agni-V missile programs, becoming the first woman to head a missile project in India. Her expertise in guidance systems and trajectory design is critical to India's ballistic missile defense capabilities.
timeline: Joined Defence Research and Development Organisation (DRDO)
Led Agni-V first test (5000+ km range)
Became Director General of Aeronautical Systems

name: Ritu Karidhal
summary: Ritu Karidhal is an Indian aerospace scientist at ISRO who served as Deputy Operations Director for the Mars Orbiter Mission (Mangalyaan) and Mission Director for the Chandrayaan-2 lunar mission. Known as the 'Rocket Woman of India,' she has been instrumental in India's space exploration achievements.
timeline: Deputy Operations Director for Mars Orbiter Mission

name: Muthulakshmi Reddy
summary: Muthulakshmi Reddy was the first Indian woman to be admitted to a men's college, the first woman house surgeon in a government hospital, and the first woman legislator in India. She founded the Adyar Cancer Institute in Madras and campaigned to abolish the devadasi system. She combined medical science with social reform.
timeline: Earned MBBS from Madras Medical College
First woman house surgeon in India

name: Iravati Karve
summary: Iravati Karve was a pioneering Indian anthropologist who conducted physical anthropology studies of the Indian population, using scientific measurements to analyze the diversity of Indian peoples. Her book Kinship Organization in India is a foundational text in Indian sociology and anthropology.

name: Kamala Sohonie
summary: Kamala Sohonie was the first Indian woman to earn a PhD in a scientific discipline. She studied at Cambridge under Nobel laureate Frederick Gowland Hopkins, researching the enzyme cytochrome c. She later worked on the nutritional value of neera (palm sap), helping address malnutrition among poor communities in India.
timeline: Fought to be admitted to IISc under C.V. Raman

name: Al-Jazari
summary: Al-Jazari was a Muslim polymath, inventor, and mechanical engineer who wrote the Book of Knowledge of Ingenious Mechanical Devices in 1206. He invented the crankshaft, water-raising machines, automatic musical instruments, and programmable automata. His elephant clock is considered one of the most sophisticated mechanical devices of the medieval period.
timeline: Born in Jazira region, Upper Mesopotamia
Became chief engineer at Artuklu Palace
Completed Book of Knowledge of Ingenious Mechanical Devices

name: Banu Musa brothers
summary: The Banu Musa brothers (Muhammad, Ahmad, and Hasan) were three 9th-century scholars in Baghdad who wrote the Book of Ingenious Devices describing over 100 mechanical devices including automatic controls, trick vessels, and musical automata. They also wrote on geometry and astronomy, and their patronage supported other scholars including al-Khwarizmi.
timeline: Worked at the House of Wisdom in Baghdad
Made contributions to mathematics and astronomy

name: Al-Farabi
summary: Al-Farabi was a renowned philosopher and scientist of the Islamic Golden Age known as the 'Second Teacher' (after Aristotle). He made contributions to logic, mathematics, music theory, physics, and cosmology. His classification of the sciences established the framework for organizing knowledge throughout the medieval Islamic world and influenced European scholasticism.
timeline: Wrote on logic, science, and music

name: Ibn Zuhr
summary: Ibn Zuhr (Avenzoar) was an Andalusian physician who made important advances in surgery, pharmacology, and clinical medicine. He was the first physician to describe mediastinal tumors, pericarditis, and intestinal tuberculosis. He performed the first tracheotomy on a goat before performing it on humans, establishing the principle of animal testing in surgery.

name: Al-Idrisi
summary: Al-Idrisi was an Arab geographer and cartographer who created the most accurate world map of the medieval period, the Tabula Rogeriana, for King Roger II of Sicily in 1154. His map and geographical compendium documented climate zones, trade routes, and natural resources across the known world with remarkable precision.
timeline: Traveled extensively through Europe and Asia
Settled in Palermo, Sicily at Roger II's court

name: Thabit ibn Qurra
summary: Thabit ibn Qurra was a mathematician, astronomer, and physician of the Islamic Golden Age who made significant contributions to number theory, geometry, and astronomy. He proved the Pythagorean theorem using a new method, discovered amicable numbers, and studied the motion of the Sun and Moon. He translated many Greek works into Arabic.
timeline: Moved to Baghdad, joined House of Wisdom

name: Al-Battani
summary: Al-Battani was one of the greatest astronomers of the Islamic Golden Age. He refined existing measurements of the length of the year and the precession of the equinoxes, and introduced the use of trigonometric methods in astronomy. His astronomical tables were used by European astronomers for centuries, including Copernicus who cited his work.

name: Ibn al-Nafis
summary: Ibn al-Nafis was a Syrian-Egyptian physician who discovered pulmonary circulation (blood flow through the lungs) three centuries before William Harvey. His Commentary on Anatomy in Avicenna's Canon correctly described how blood passes from the right to left heart through the lungs, contradicting Galen's theory of invisible pores.
timeline: Studied medicine at Nuri Hospital, Damascus
Published Commentary on Anatomy describing pulmonary circulation
Became chief physician at al-Mansuri Hospital, Cairo

name: Abbas ibn Firnas
summary: Abbas ibn Firnas was an Andalusian polymath who is credited with one of the earliest attempts at human flight. In 875 CE, at age 65, he built a glider with feathered wings and reportedly flew for a significant distance before crash-landing. He also developed clear glass, a water clock, and planetarium. He is considered a pioneer of aviation.
timeline: Built a planetarium with moving stars
Attempted glider flight from a tower in Cordoba

name: Al-Zahrawi
summary: Al-Zahrawi (Albucasis) was an Andalusian surgeon considered the father of modern surgery. His encyclopedic Al-Tasrif described over 200 surgical instruments and surgical procedures including catgut sutures, forceps delivery, and thyroidectomy. The surgical section was used as a standard textbook in European medical schools for 500 years.
timeline: Born in Zahra, near Cordoba, Al-Andalus

name: Fatima al-Fihri
summary: Fatima al-Fihri founded the University of al-Qarawiyyin in Fez, Morocco in 859 CE, which UNESCO and Guinness World Records recognize as the oldest continuously operating university in the world. Her establishment of an institution dedicated to learning and scholarship predates the founding of European universities by centuries.
timeline: University became center of Islamic scholarship

name: Samuel Ajayi Crowther
summary: Samuel Ajayi Crowther was a Nigerian linguist and the first African Anglican bishop. While primarily a religious figure, his systematic linguistic analysis of the Yoruba language produced the first Yoruba grammar and dictionary, and he developed writing systems for multiple West African languages, demonstrating scientific rigor in linguistic documentation.
timeline: Freed from slave ship by British Navy

name: Thomas Odhiambo
summary: Thomas Odhiambo was a Kenyan entomologist who founded the International Centre of Insect Physiology and Ecology (ICIPE) in Nairobi. He pioneered research on insect-plant interactions in African agriculture and trained a generation of African scientists. He advocated for building indigenous scientific capacity in Africa.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Cambridge
Developed insect pest management for Africa

name: Wangari Maathai
summary: Wangari Maathai was a Kenyan environmental scientist and political activist who won the 2004 Nobel Peace Prize. She founded the Green Belt Movement in 1977, which has planted over 51 million trees in Kenya. She was the first woman in East and Central Africa to earn a doctoral degree in biology. Her work combined environmental science with community empowerment.
timeline: First East African woman to earn PhD in biology

name: Calestous Juma
summary: Calestous Juma was a Kenyan-American scholar at Harvard Kennedy School who studied the role of science, technology, and innovation in economic development. His work on technology adoption, agricultural biotechnology, and African development influenced global development policy. His book Innovation and Its Enemies analyzed resistance to new technologies.
timeline: Founded African Centre for Technology Studies
Served on UN Millennium Project Task Force

name: Quarraisha Abdool Karim
summary: Quarraisha Abdool Karim is a South African epidemiologist who has been a leading researcher in HIV prevention. Her CAPRISA 004 trial in 2010 demonstrated the first evidence that a microbicide gel could prevent HIV infection in women. She has published over 300 papers and has been recognized by Time magazine as one of the 100 most influential people.
timeline: CAPRISA 004 trial showed microbicide effectiveness against HIV
Elected Foreign Associate of US National Academy of Sciences

name: Francisca Nneka Okeke
summary: Francisca Nneka Okeke is a Nigerian physicist who studies the effects of solar activity on the Earth's ionosphere and magnetic field. She was the first female professor of physics at the University of Nigeria, Nsukka, and won the L'Oréal-UNESCO Award for Women in Science for Africa in 2013. Her research on equatorial electrojet currents has been internationally recognized.
timeline: Won L'Oreal-UNESCO Award for Women in Science

name: Segenet Kelemu
summary: Segenet Kelemu is an Ethiopian plant pathologist who serves as Director General of the International Centre of Insect Physiology and Ecology (ICIPE). Her research on grass-endophyte symbiosis has improved tropical forage crops. She has worked to develop sustainable pest management solutions for African agriculture.
timeline: Earned PhD from Kansas State University

name: Felix Konotey-Ahulu
summary: Felix Konotey-Ahulu was a Ghanaian physician and the world's foremost expert on sickle cell disease in Africa. His comprehensive studies of sickle cell disease across West African populations identified clinical variations, genetic patterns, and treatment approaches. His 1991 book 'The Sickle Cell Disease Patient' remains a definitive clinical reference.
timeline: Born in Odumase-Krobo, Gold Coast (now Ghana)
Qualified as physician at London Hospital
Returned to Ghana, began sickle cell research
Established sickle cell clinic at Korle Bu Hospital
Published The Sickle Cell Disease Patient

name: Cheick Modibo Diarra
summary: Cheick Modibo Diarra is a Malian astrophysicist who served as a navigator for NASA's Mars missions including Magellan, Mars Observer, and Mars Pathfinder. He is one of the most prominent African scientists in space exploration. He later served as Prime Minister of Mali and has promoted science education across Africa.
timeline: Born in Nioro du Sahel, Mali
Founded Pathfinder Foundation for Education and Development
Served as Prime Minister of Mali

name: Philip Emeagwali
summary: Philip Emeagwali is a Nigerian-American computer scientist who in 1989 used a Connection Machine to perform 3.1 billion calculations per second on a petroleum reservoir simulation, winning the Gordon Bell Prize. His work on parallel computing demonstrated that massively parallel processing could solve practical engineering problems.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Michigan
Won Gordon Bell Prize for parallel computing achievement

name: Vera Rubin
summary: Vera Rubin was an American astronomer who provided the first strong evidence for the existence of dark matter. By measuring the rotation curves of galaxies, she showed that galaxies rotate much faster than expected, implying the presence of vast amounts of unseen matter. Her work fundamentally changed our understanding of the universe.
timeline: Measured galaxy rotation curves showing dark matter evidence

name: Chien-Shiung Wu
summary: Chien-Shiung Wu was a Chinese-American physicist who conducted the Wu experiment in 1956, disproving the law of conservation of parity in weak nuclear interactions. Known as the 'First Lady of Physics,' her experimental work led to the Nobel Prize for Tsung-Dao Lee and Chen-Ning Yang, though she was controversially excluded from the award.
timeline: Lee and Yang won Nobel Prize (Wu excluded)
Became first female president of American Physical Society

name: Maryam Mirzakhani
summary: Maryam Mirzakhani was an Iranian-American mathematician who in 2014 became the first woman and the first Iranian to win the Fields Medal, mathematics' highest honor. She made groundbreaking contributions to the theory of Riemann surfaces and their moduli spaces. She died of breast cancer at age 40.
timeline: Won International Mathematical Olympiad gold medal
Won International Mathematical Olympiad gold with perfect score

name: Katalin Kariko
summary: Katalin Kariko is a Hungarian-American biochemist whose decades of research on mRNA technology laid the foundation for the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna COVID-19 vaccines. Despite years of rejection and funding difficulties, she persisted in developing modified nucleosides that made mRNA therapeutics possible. She won the 2023 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine.
timeline: Published key paper on modified nucleosides with Drew Weissman
mRNA technology used in COVID-19 vaccines
Won Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: Gladys West
summary: Gladys West is an American mathematician whose work at the Naval Surface Warfare Center was instrumental in developing the Global Positioning System (GPS). She programmed satellite geodesy models that produced increasingly accurate calculations of the Earth's shape, which became the basis for GPS technology used by billions of people worldwide.
timeline: Hired at Naval Surface Warfare Center, Dahlgren
Recommended for project leading to GPS development
Completed geodetic model for GPS accuracy
Inducted into Air Force Space and Missile Pioneers Hall of Fame

name: Esther Lederberg
summary: Esther Lederberg was an American microbiologist who discovered lambda phage (a bacterial virus) and developed replica plating, a technique fundamental to microbial genetics. Despite these major contributions, her work was often overshadowed by her husband Joshua Lederberg, who received the Nobel Prize partly based on work she contributed to.
timeline: Developed replica plating technique with Joshua Lederberg

name: Nettie Stevens
summary: Nettie Stevens was an American geneticist who discovered that sex is determined by chromosomes (XX and XY) in 1905. Working with mealworms, she demonstrated that the X and Y chromosomes determine sex, one of the most important discoveries in genetics. Her male colleague Edmund Wilson often received more credit for parallel findings.
timeline: Earned PhD from Bryn Mawr College
Studied at University of Würzburg with Boveri
Died of breast cancer at age 50

name: Lise Meitner
summary: Lise Meitner was an Austrian-Swedish physicist who first explained nuclear fission in 1939. Despite her crucial role in the discovery, the Nobel Prize was awarded only to her longtime collaborator Otto Hahn. Einstein called her the 'German Marie Curie.' Element 109, meitnerium, is named in her honor.
timeline: Second woman to earn physics doctorate from University of Vienna
Explained nuclear fission with Otto Frisch
Hahn alone received Nobel Prize (controversial omission)

name: Cecilia Payne-Gaposchkin
summary: Cecilia Payne-Gaposchkin was a British-American astronomer who in her 1925 PhD thesis determined that stars are composed primarily of hydrogen and helium, contradicting the prevailing belief that Earth and stars had similar compositions. Her thesis has been described as the most brilliant PhD thesis ever written in astronomy.
timeline: PhD thesis proved stars are mainly hydrogen and helium
Given title of 'Astronomer' at Harvard (not professor)
First female full professor at Harvard

name: Jocelyn Bell Burnell
summary: Jocelyn Bell Burnell is a British-Irish astrophysicist who as a graduate student in 1967 discovered pulsars (rapidly rotating neutron stars), one of the greatest astronomical discoveries of the 20th century. The Nobel Prize for the discovery was controversially awarded to her supervisor Antony Hewish and Martin Ryle, but not to her.
timeline: Nobel Prize given to Hewish and Ryle (Bell excluded)
Won Breakthrough Prize in Fundamental Physics ($3 million)
Donated entire prize money to help underrepresented students

name: Mae Jemison
summary: Mae Jemison is an American physician, engineer, and NASA astronaut who became the first African American woman to travel in space in 1992 aboard Space Shuttle Endeavour. She conducted experiments on weightlessness and motion sickness during the mission. After leaving NASA, she founded the Jemison Group technology company and the 100 Year Starship project.
timeline: Earned BS in chemical engineering from Stanford
First African American woman in space (STS-47)
Named principal of 100 Year Starship project

name: Patricia Bath
summary: Patricia Bath was an American ophthalmologist who invented the Laserphaco Probe for cataract surgery, becoming the first African American woman to receive a medical patent. She co-founded the American Institute for the Prevention of Blindness and developed community ophthalmology, bringing eye care to underserved populations.
timeline: Co-founded American Institute for the Prevention of Blindness
Invented Laserphaco Probe for cataract surgery
First African American woman to receive medical patent

name: Flossie Wong-Staal
summary: Flossie Wong-Staal was a Chinese-American virologist who was the first scientist to clone HIV and determine the function of its genes. Her work was essential for developing the HIV blood test and understanding the virus's mechanisms. She was ranked as the top woman scientist of the 1980s by the Institute for Scientific Information.
timeline: First to clone HIV and map its genes
Joined University of California, San Diego

name: Youyou Tu
summary: Tu Youyou is a Chinese pharmaceutical chemist who discovered artemisinin, a drug that has saved millions of lives from malaria. She found the compound in sweet wormwood (Artemisia annua) using traditional Chinese medicine texts as a guide. She won the 2015 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine, the first Chinese Nobel laureate in the sciences.
timeline: Graduated from Peking University School of Medicine
Appointed head of Project 523 malaria research
Won Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: Qian Xuesen
summary: Qian Xuesen was a Chinese-American aerospace engineer who co-founded the Jet Propulsion Laboratory at Caltech and later became the father of China's space and missile programs. Deported from the US during McCarthyism, he returned to China and led the development of China's first ballistic missiles, satellites, and space program.
timeline: Moved to United States, studied at MIT and Caltech
Led China's first ballistic missile test

name: Yuan Longping
summary: Yuan Longping was a Chinese agronomist known as the 'Father of Hybrid Rice.' His development of the first successful hybrid rice varieties in the 1970s increased rice yields by 20%, feeding an additional 250 million people annually. His work is credited with helping China and many developing nations achieve food security.
timeline: Hybrid rice deployed nationwide in China

name: Zhang Heng
summary: Zhang Heng was a Chinese polymath of the Han Dynasty who invented the world's first seismoscope to detect earthquakes in 132 CE. He also invented an improved armillary sphere for astronomical observation, calculated pi to about 3.1466, and produced the most detailed star catalog of his time with 2,500 stars in 320 constellations.
timeline: Born in Nanyang, Han Dynasty China
Invented the first seismoscope (Houfeng Didong Yi)

name: Su Song
summary: Su Song was a Chinese polymath of the Song Dynasty who built the world's first astronomical clock tower in 1088. Standing 12 meters tall, it featured an escapement mechanism, an armillary sphere, and a celestial globe, all powered by water. He also compiled a comprehensive pharmaceutical treatise documenting over 1,000 medicinal substances.
timeline: Born in Fujian, Song Dynasty China
Published New Design for an Armillary Sphere and Celestial Globe

name: Shen Kuo
summary: Shen Kuo was a Chinese polymath of the Song Dynasty whose Dream Pool Essays (1088) described the magnetic compass needle, movable type printing, and geological concepts including fossils and climate change. He discovered magnetic declination, described erosion and sedimentation, and made advances in mathematics, astronomy, and medicine.
timeline: Born in Hangzhou, Song Dynasty China
Led astronomical observations and calendar reform

name: Bi Sheng
summary: Bi Sheng was a Chinese artisan who invented movable type printing around 1040 CE, approximately 400 years before Johannes Gutenberg's printing press in Europe. He created individual characters from baked clay that could be rearranged and reused, revolutionizing information technology. His invention is documented by Shen Kuo.
timeline: Invented movable type printing using baked clay

name: Cai Lun
summary: Cai Lun was a Chinese eunuch court official who is credited with inventing papermaking in 105 CE. He developed a process using tree bark, hemp, rags, and fishnets to create a writing surface that was cheaper and easier to produce than silk or bamboo strips. His invention of paper is considered one of the most important in human history.
timeline: Born in Guiyang, Han Dynasty China
Put in charge of manufacturing instruments and weapons
Presented improved papermaking process to Emperor He

name: Mario Molina
summary: Mario Molina was a Mexican-American chemist who co-discovered that chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) were depleting the ozone layer. His research led to the Montreal Protocol, the most successful international environmental agreement, banning CFCs. He shared the 1995 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for this work that literally saved Earth's protective ozone layer.
timeline: Joined UC Irvine, studied atmospheric chemistry
Published paper on CFCs and ozone depletion with Rowland

name: Carlos Finlay
summary: Carlos Finlay was a Cuban physician who identified the Aedes aegypti mosquito as the vector for yellow fever transmission in 1881, decades before it was accepted by the medical community. His theory, initially ridiculed, was later confirmed by Walter Reed's Yellow Fever Commission. His discovery saved countless lives and enabled the completion of the Panama Canal.
timeline: Earned medical degree from Jefferson Medical College
Proposed mosquito transmission theory for yellow fever
Theory confirmed by Walter Reed Commission
Yellow fever controlled in Cuba and Panama

name: Luis Miramontes
summary: Luis Miramontes was a Mexican chemist who at age 26 co-invented norethindrone, the chemical compound that became the basis for the first oral contraceptive pill. His synthesis of the progestin in 1951 was one of the most socially impactful chemical achievements of the 20th century, fundamentally changing human reproductive control.
timeline: Co-invented compound used in first oral contraceptive

name: Cesar Milstein
summary: Cesar Milstein was an Argentine-British biochemist who developed the technique for producing monoclonal antibodies in 1975, one of the most important tools in modern medicine and biotechnology. He shared the 1984 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine. Monoclonal antibodies are now used in pregnancy tests, cancer treatment, and COVID-19 therapy.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Cambridge
Returned to Argentina, then back to Cambridge
Developed monoclonal antibody technique with Georges Kohler
Won Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: Bernardo Houssay
summary: Bernardo Houssay was an Argentine physiologist who won the 1947 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for discovering the role of pituitary hormones in regulating blood sugar. He was the first Latin American to win a Nobel Prize in the sciences and founded CONICET, Argentina's national research council.
timeline: Became professor at University of Buenos Aires
Discovered pituitary gland's role in sugar metabolism
Won Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine

name: Abdus Salam
summary: Abdus Salam was a Pakistani theoretical physicist who shared the 1979 Nobel Prize in Physics for his work on electroweak unification, showing that electromagnetism and the weak nuclear force are aspects of a single force. He was the first Muslim and first Pakistani to win a Nobel Prize in science. He founded the International Centre for Theoretical Physics in Trieste.
timeline: Born in Jhang, British India (now Pakistan)
Founded International Centre for Theoretical Physics

name: Nergis Mavalvala
summary: Nergis Mavalvala is a Pakistani-American astrophysicist who was part of the LIGO team that made the first direct detection of gravitational waves in 2015, confirming Einstein's century-old prediction. She serves as Dean of the MIT School of Science and has made important contributions to quantum measurement techniques used in gravitational wave detection.
timeline: Became Dean of MIT School of Science

name: Omar Yaghi
summary: Omar Yaghi is a Jordanian-American chemist who invented metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) and covalent organic frameworks (COFs), entirely new classes of porous materials. His reticular chemistry has applications in carbon capture, hydrogen storage, water harvesting from air, and drug delivery. He is one of the most cited chemists in the world.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Illinois
Demonstrated water harvesting from desert air using MOFs

name: Manu Prakash
summary: Manu Prakash is an Indian-American bioengineer at Stanford who invented the Foldscope, a $1 paper microscope, and the Paperfuge, a 20-cent centrifuge. His 'frugal science' approach creates ultra-low-cost scientific instruments accessible to anyone in the world, democratizing scientific tools. His lab has distributed millions of Foldscopes worldwide.

name: Hayat Sindi
summary: Hayat Sindi is a Saudi Arabian biotechnologist who co-founded Diagnostics For All, a non-profit developing low-cost paper-based diagnostic tests for developing countries. She was one of the first Saudi women to earn a PhD in biotechnology (from Cambridge) and was named a UNESCO Goodwill Ambassador for Sciences.
timeline: Earned PhD in biotechnology from Cambridge
Named in National Geographic Emerging Explorers

name: Salim Abdool Karim
summary: Salim Abdool Karim is a South African epidemiologist who has been a leading researcher on HIV/AIDS and COVID-19. He chaired South Africa's COVID-19 Ministerial Advisory Committee and led groundbreaking research on HIV prevention, including the CAPRISA trials. His work has been crucial for understanding infectious disease in Africa.
timeline: Chaired South Africa's COVID-19 advisory committee

name: David Sengeh
summary: David Sengeh is a Sierra Leonean biomedical engineer who developed comfortable prosthetic sockets using 3D printing and MRI data at MIT Media Lab. He became Sierra Leone's Chief Innovation Officer and Minister of Education, applying technology to solve development challenges in one of the world's poorest countries.
timeline: Earned PhD from MIT Media Lab
Became Sierra Leone's Chief Innovation Officer

name: Treena Livingston Arinzeh
summary: Treena Livingston Arinzeh is an American biomedical engineer who has pioneered tissue engineering and stem cell research for bone and cartilage repair. Her work on using mesenchymal stem cells for tissue regeneration has advanced orthopedic medicine. She was the first African American woman to receive the NSF CAREER Award in her field.
timeline: Joined New Jersey Institute of Technology
Advanced piezoelectric scaffolds for tissue engineering

name: Feng Zhang
summary: Feng Zhang is a Chinese-American biomedical engineer at MIT who was one of the first scientists to adapt the CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing system for use in human cells. His work has been central to the CRISPR revolution in genetic engineering. He also developed optogenetics tools and founded Editas Medicine to bring CRISPR therapies to patients.
timeline: Published CRISPR-Cas9 use in human cells

name: He Jiankui
summary: He Jiankui is a Chinese biophysicist who in 2018 created the world's first gene-edited babies using CRISPR, modifying embryos to be resistant to HIV. The experiment was condemned by the scientific community as unethical and premature. He was sentenced to three years in prison. The case raised global debates about gene editing ethics.
timeline: Joined Southern University of Science and Technology
Announced birth of gene-edited twin girls
Experiment condemned by global scientific community
Sentenced to three years in prison

name: Demis Hassabis
summary: Demis Hassabis is a British AI researcher and neuroscientist who co-founded DeepMind, the AI lab that created AlphaGo (which defeated the world Go champion) and AlphaFold (which predicted the 3D structure of nearly all known proteins). He won the 2024 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for AlphaFold's contribution to protein structure prediction.
timeline: Earned PhD in cognitive neuroscience from UCL
AlphaGo defeated world Go champion Lee Sedol

name: Fei-Fei Li
summary: Fei-Fei Li is a Chinese-American computer scientist at Stanford who created ImageNet, the massive visual database that catalyzed the deep learning revolution in computer vision. Her work enabled the breakthrough in image recognition that transformed artificial intelligence. She co-directs the Stanford Human-Centered AI Institute.
timeline: ImageNet challenge catalyzed deep learning breakthrough
Chief Scientist at Google Cloud (on leave from Stanford)

name: Yann LeCun
summary: Yann LeCun is a French-American computer scientist who is one of the founding fathers of deep learning. He developed convolutional neural networks (CNNs), the technology behind modern image recognition, facial recognition, and autonomous vehicles. He shared the 2018 Turing Award with Geoffrey Hinton and Yoshua Bengio.
timeline: Became Chief AI Scientist at Meta (Facebook)

name: Yoshua Bengio
summary: Yoshua Bengio is a Canadian computer scientist who is one of the three founding fathers of deep learning, sharing the 2018 Turing Award with Geoffrey Hinton and Yann LeCun. His research on recurrent neural networks, word embeddings, and generative adversarial networks has been foundational for modern AI including language models and AI safety research.
timeline: Published on neural network language models

name: Andrew Ng
summary: Andrew Ng is a British-American computer scientist who co-founded Coursera and Google Brain, and served as Chief Scientist at Baidu. He is one of the most influential figures in AI education, having taught machine learning to millions through online courses. His work on deep learning and AI democratization has shaped the modern AI industry.
timeline: Founded Google Brain deep learning project

name: John Jumper
summary: John Jumper is an American AI researcher at DeepMind who led the development of AlphaFold2, which solved the 50-year-old protein folding problem. AlphaFold2 can predict protein structures with atomic-level accuracy, revolutionizing structural biology and drug discovery. He shared the 2024 Nobel Prize in Chemistry with Demis Hassabis.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Chicago
AlphaFold2 solved protein structure prediction at CASP14
AlphaFold predicted structures for 200 million proteins

name: Jennifer Doudna
summary: Jennifer Doudna is an American biochemist who co-developed the CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing technology, one of the most significant inventions in the history of biology. With Emmanuelle Charpentier, she demonstrated how this bacterial immune system could be repurposed to edit any DNA sequence. They shared the 2020 Nobel Prize in Chemistry.
timeline: Co-founded Intellia Therapeutics and Mammoth Biosciences
Won Nobel Prize in Chemistry with Emmanuelle Charpentier

name: Emmanuelle Charpentier
summary: Emmanuelle Charpentier is a French microbiologist who co-developed the CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing technology with Jennifer Doudna. Her discovery of tracrRNA and its role in the CRISPR system was the key insight that enabled the development of this revolutionary gene editing tool. She shared the 2020 Nobel Prize in Chemistry.
timeline: Moved to research positions in Europe
Co-published CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing with Doudna
Founded Max Planck Unit for the Science of Pathogens
